topic.title: Creating sites
topic.body: Any resources people can suggest for creating sites for zeronet?

1523623838_1GM5NViQbp18za5zzjhvffcHehfpe.body:
> [z00mb1e](#comment_3_1Pw5rRdGwgJADc4g1BQMtPndAjNgtcWtJz): It's funny, how people criticise Telegram for "not being" secure, but mainly Telegram gets blocked...

Popular â‰  Secure

> [mrzer0](#comment_2_15A6BLji3Z885NxTEJiNvffwxigHtuPmvZ): telegram is still the best chat service out there. if you have smth important to discuss or want to be anonymous there are way better alternatives, yes. but none of them has the feature set telegram has. and it's already 100x more secure than any other commercial chat service

There are better chat services out there with the same or more features and even commercial applications like whatsapp and LINE have significantly stronger security than telegram

1522586677_1CuFXko1Q3MMRkboFygeu9DxNVAFG.body: ZeroNet currently seems to rely on tor for anonymity and resisting censorship on the consumer end. It's main strength is being able to serve dynamic content that can't be taken down by seizing a server like traditional web sites or even tor hidden services. IPFS and dat do something similar but currently aren't very newbie friendly or support dynamic content (yet).

1524589266_1KDRKDBSjdQmoGoQo3fdCHia7mp2G.body: nicotine is addictive so if you consume more than a trace amount regularly you have a pretty high risk of developing an addiction.

> [neokektus](#comment_7_1KDRKDBSjdQmoGoQo3fdCHia7mp2Gmc8xt): Interesting you say that cannabis is not addictive?Please excuse me for being so direct. I'm serious about my questions. [...]

Cannabis is not chemicaly addictive like drugs such as nicotine, alcohol and amphetamines, opiates or foods such as sugar, casein (found in dairy) and so on. However as disorders such as gambling, video game, or sex addiction prove, it is possible for people to become mentally addicted to activities even if they are not consuming an addictive substance. It is possible to be addicted to any activity/situation, including smoking marijuana in this sense. In your case I would try to kick the tobacco habit first as that seems the most likely substance you're consuming to cause an addiction

1524602122_1F9qtxgSgbkeJX7NT2BARwR8XCn1X.body: I don't think a video specifically about the behavior patterns of medically diagnosed psychopaths would ease my anxiety, personally.

1524956365_14krSqWKV9nfHitvW7X3YYbyXWnkV.body: Applying Game Theory to human interaction is not very sensible. The idea of using Game Theory in a sociopolitical context was developed by John Nash while he was suffering from severe paranoid Schizophrenia and he disavowed it after recovering. He later died in a car crash due to not wearing a seatbelt so all in all, not a guy I would suggest modeling your life or world views after even if he was a genius when it came to mathematics.

> [caryoscelus](#comment_75_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): Regardless of the truthfullness of conclusions/your initial statement, your argument is somewhat fallacious. It might be considered sound (though not necessarily true) that "modeling your life or world views after" "certain person who died due to not wearing seatbelt", but you also imply (without any sound proofs) that everybody who applies "game theory to human interaction" is following John Nash. While it may be vacuously true from historical point of view, it certainly isn't from the everyday logic (it may also be especially useless if someone would point to most likely existed person who did the similar (not necessarily called the same) thing before Nash). I'm pretty sure that most (but, in any case, at least some) people apply game theory to human interaction without any knowledge of who Nash is or what he thought and how his views developed. [...]

Obviously the primary reason you shouldn't be using Game Theory as a model for human behavior is that it's empirically been proven to be a terrible predictor of human behavior :P 

That said, it's important to know where an idea came from in the first place, in evaluating an idea, especially for a layperson (I strongly doubt sylvaine has a math or sociology phd) who lacks most of the background information on a subject. The world is too complex and life is too short for one person to understand the totality in human knowledge, that's why experts exist.

That is why I think its relevant to someone discovering these ideas to know that they were first developed by a paranoid schizophrenic.

In a sense, anyone applying game theory to sociopolitical behavior is following John Nash, regardless of if they agree with his (since disavowed) ideas since he built the original foundation all the work that has followed is built off of or adapted from.

> The problem is that it isn't possible to empirically prove anything like that. The closest would be "most people who are using game theory that way fail terribly at it", which does seem to be true. But it doesn't follow that game theory per se is inapplicable.

How many complete and total failures do you think one should experience before considering other options? People use Game Theory in this way because they want it to be true, despite all evidence being to the contrary.

> So-called "experts" would say opposite opinions, so you'd have an expert-choosing criteria anyway. And gaining that might be no simpler than generic idea criteria.

Disagree. It's much simpler, though still complex, to evaluate experts in the context of the current academic context than it is to become an expert in multiple academic fields yourself, plus you still have too little time to listen to every single person who has an opinion on a particular subject.

> Yeah, and in a sense anyone who draw pictures is following Hitler. The problem here is how to define what kind of "in a sense" is relevant and what kind is not. If all you can come up with is "in a sense", it probably isn't relevant.

Painting existed before the 1900s you doofus.

> Then you've no room to argue for or against an idea. You can provide someone else's claim and suggest that you trust this source, but you have no room to argue the point.

I've never said you can't discuss the merits of an idea unless you're an expert, but considering the source of an idea is a useful way of filtering out the bullshit before going deeper.

1526051818_126w3qujTWkNgjDDZQ7Evq46ZkLkA.body:
> Pedophiles get a bad rap. It's a sexual orientation just like being straight or gay.
No, it's a mental disorder. I have sympathy for pedophiles who try to live virtuously despite their affliction but people who actively harm kids or get their jollies watching kids be harmed are scum. If you want to have a nuanced discussion about this topic, defending a freak who sells pictures of kids being abused is a bad place to start.

> [shitchell](#comment_60_1LybGoL99LBuYE8ZtwgJC8dxkii3UmYKpo): Really? According to who? You? Because the DSM-V disagrees. Pedophilia was removed from the DSM just like homosexuality was long ago. The 3 qualifications for a "pedophilia disorder" are: [...]

You're confusing the diagnostic diagnostic criteria for pedophilic disorder, with pedophilia. Pedophilia is still classified as a paraphilia (aberrant sexual interest). It was referred to as a sexual orientation in one paragraph due to a typo in an early version of the DSM-V but this an error and was corrected in subsequent updates to the manual. 

The diagnostic criteria for pedophilic disorder includes having acted on pedophilic urges so any sick fuck buying and selling CP qualifies as both a pedophile AND having pedophilic disorder. Going by the DSM-V you can be a pedophile but not suffer from paraphilic or pedophilic disorders only if you are not emotionally distressed or socially impaired by your urges AND also do not have any significant risk of acting on them.

Additionally, the DSM-V's primary purpose is to assist psychiatric professionals in making diagnoses so the criteria have to be observable and quantifiable in a clinical setting. This is not the same as the colloquial, or legal definition of a disorder.

> [kaffie](#comment_693_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Sure. The exact pizzagate stuff isn't a guilty verdict.But it definitely is super suspicious. It's all the stuff connected to it that's a slam dunk. The most damning to me (that hasn't been cleaned up by the elite yet) is the elpida pedo logo painted on their mural. Here's the pic on the official radcliffe foundation website. So some background details: the logo you see on the far left is a recognized symbol pedophiles use to communicate with one another. This has been recognized by the FBI and used to bust pedo circles. On the right of the image you can clearly see elpida's name, confirming this is indeed a mural for elpida. That pedo symbol was actually their logo, but now they changed it, killed their social media pages and websites, and removed all scraps from the internet. The radcliffe foundation site confirms this is indeed elpida's mural. [...]

oh my god this is so fucking stupid, listen to yourself. This is some Alex Jones shit.

> [kaffie](#comment_695_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): You can sling insults all you want, but you can't debunk my observations, as you can clearly make them yourself.

Do you have anything to support your claims about "elpida" being a pedophile symbol that isn't a pizzagate conspiracy site? If it's been used by the FBI there should be lots of references to it on other sources. Not to mention the complete absurdity of a global, multitrillion dollar child porn ring communicating with what are essentially hobo glyphs.

> Like the talks of $65,000 pizza

A couple of random stratfor employees speculating about how much the whitehouse spends on food is not evidence of anything. Someone at my job made a joke about the boss spending "like a million dollars" on the huge overabundance of catering at the office christmas party last year. I guess we're also a secret pedophile ring according to you?

> pornographic images posted by Comet Pizza

Citation needed. What are these images, how are the pornographic? Is all porn now connected to child abuse? Is anyone who posts pictures involving adult nudity a pedophile?

> Or the literal pedophilic comments made towards children on their social media.

Citation needed. Like most/all pizzagate "evidence" this sounds like mental gymnastics akin to thinking anything with the initials CP is connected to child porn. Literal insanity.

> Straight from wikileaks. These symbols are used in general, not just for the elite. I'm sure the wealthy/elite probably have other symbols we aren't aware of.

A triangular spiral is way too common to mean much on its own. I guess this company is also run by pedophiles? https://www.vectorstock.com/royalty-free-vector/business-abstract-spiral-triangle-icon-vector-16153836. The graffiti you posted earlier doesn't even match the FBI document (different horizontal and vertical orientation, different number of lines)

> I can't pull them up at the moment (in a public area). Just look up archives of comet pizza's instagram. You can see for yourself. Half naked people, very sexual and suggestive images. Kids tied up. People commenting "yum" on pics of kids.

I have. First of all it's the owner's instagram, not the business page. Second it just looks like stupid DC artsy bullshit and pics of his kids. Other than the one with his kids arms masking taped on a table there's nothing suggesting pedophilia and that one just looks like a shitty joke.

If this is really all you've got, it seems pretty weak.

> [kaffie](#comment_698_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Those don't match whatsoever. So no. The company also has nothing to do with children, nor is connected to people suspected of child trafficking. [...]

They matcher closer than the mural... Are you blind? The spiral on the mural doesn't even have the same number of sides.

> Pornographic images are "DC artsy bullshit"? For a "family" restaurant?

There are zero "pornographic" images on the restaraunts instagram and there never have been. The owner's personal Instragram has a couple sexually suggestive artworks and some nude photos. Big difference between a personal and business accounts.

I'm sorry but this seems like a mental illness to me, please go see a psychiatrist.
